utterances.text: (upbeat music)
- Hello friends and welcome to Gamer Radio episode zero.
Yeah, it's a holiday test episode.
I'm pushing the buttons and running the board.
Our host is here, Mr. Dominic.
Hello, Mike.
- Hello, I'm Chris and welcome to the Gamer Radio.
- Oh no, another voice.
- Another voice.
- It's only a few degrees off from Jar Jar too, you know.
- You know, they might be cousins, Mario and Jar Jar.
They're both like a dark backstory there.
- God, I could only imagine the thick fan
is probably getting written right now.
So we're not doing Coda Radio.
We're taking a moment out of the holidays
to try a little test episode.
We want people's feedback.
I suppose if gaming isn't your thing
and you're only here for the coding
and the development and the business,
well, you could probably skip, that's fine.
But we'd love to know your feedback.
You can drop us a line at the regular contact spots.
And maybe we should start with, you know,
why we're talking about gaming on the holidays of all times.
Just a few days before the big guy arrives down the chimney.
- That's right.
Well, I think there's a couple of reasons, right?
We both have kids and I'd wager we're gonna be doing
quite a bit of gaming with the little ones.
- I love it. - Over this break.
Yep. - Oh yeah.
Oh, it's already begun.
- It's already begun. - Yeah.
(laughing)
- Yeah, but the Pokemon cards are very much out.
- Man, we have to bring them with us
whenever we go places where we're gonna be a while
and it's so much hassle.
I don't know if you have to do this with your kid,
but like, well, whatever they're really into,
we always have to haul and bring it with us.
And right now it's Pokemon cards.
And I'm trying to convince them,
what if we just took pictures of them
and just brought digital photos of them?
Would that be enough?
No, Dad. (laughing)
- Yeah, I have a very similar problem.
There is the Pokemon iPad TCG game too,
but I try to limit the iPad time pretty severely.
Just something I'm sure we'll talk about at some point.
- Sure, sure. - Yeah.
My favorite thing is my son likes somebody
that's looking at his Pokemon cards.
Instead of picking one up out of the deck
and looking at it, he likes to pick up the whole stack,
which I sleeve everything so they're slippery
and bam, they're always get launched
across the restaurant or whatever.
- So I mean, clearly it's very enjoyable,
so that's one of the reasons we do it. (laughing)
- Yes, lots of fun.
- I don't know, there's something too
about that shared feelings.
So they just, my kids just unearthed a game
that they played when they were really young,
all three of them.
By the grace of the Apple App Store,
they were able to recover games
that are no longer actually available for purchase
or download in the App Store,
but if you go into a family member's purchase history,
if one family member purchased it way back in the day,
you can still download it, and if you're lucky, it'll run.
And so they came across some
of their early childhood games this way.
And the nostalgia was real.
Like they were really in like nostalgia heaven for a bit.
And it's fun because I had those same feelings,
and I enjoy recreating that experience for them.
And some of these games, I still have access to.
I don't know if those iPad games
they'll have access to in 30 years, but I'm thankful.
- Well, isn't that the challenge, right?
A bunch of games this year just died
because their backing web services got turned off.
- Yeah, and that is an unfortunate thing.
You install some of these games,
and they just simply don't have the backend services anymore.
And that makes me a little sad,
but I also feel like the classics,
the ones people really, really love,
people go out of their way.
Like I have seen MMOs that got shut down,
and the community recreated
the entire MMO backend infrastructure.
So it just depends, right?
- Great example of that is Matrix Online, right?
The community just reversed engineered
the quote unquote API calls, right?
The networking stack to create the game
as it was when it was shut down.
And I believe they continued
and actually added an expansion that was half developed.
- Wow, you know, I'm old enough to remember
when it was kind of a bad thing to be into video games.
And now everyone has a video game console in their pocket.
Well, if you'll allow the broadest definition of the term.
But you know what I mean?
I think it really changed over the last 10 years.
Maybe I'm wrong, but it felt like
the last 10 years things really shifted.
Like it was okay to be a Nintendo fan
and that kind of stuff, but that was like the edges of it.
And now it feels like gaming culture is not only embraced,
but it's a niche that the market is happily serving.
- Yeah, I would even say it's gone mainstream, right?
- Yeah, well, app stores I think are part of that.
- Yeah, well, for sure, for sure the app stores.
I, you know, it's curious to see,
will things like Xbox Live,
oh my God, what do they call it, xCloud?
- Yeah, the stream.
- Is that gonna, does that seem to have been a boon
for like the back catalog of previous generation games?
You figure you pay over 14 bucks a month
and you've got what, what is it like 800
and something games now?
- Oh my gosh, is it?
- Yeah, it's a lot, especially if you count the,
like the original Xbox and some of the like Sega collection
and 360 games that they have on there.
- You know what is interesting about that is
that's the compatibility problem solved once, isn't it?
Traditionally with consoles, not so bad on PCs,
but on consoles, there was times when they just
were not necessarily binary compatible
with the previous console, so you couldn't run the game.
And, you know, sometimes after the console
had been out for a while, they'd come up with an emulator
and the performance would be pretty equivalent.
But that problem's solved because now it's just
an H.264 stream to the whatever console,
doesn't matter what CPU it's using.
Could be a tiny little ARM chip
or it could be a massive x86 box.
- From your lips to God's ears,
there's a pretty well-known problem with PS3 games,
especially like Metal Gear Solid 4 in particular,
that because of the, let's say, unique cell processor
that the PS3 had, it's not really easy to emulate
on the PS5 or PS4.
- Right.
- But in theory, if you had, yeah,
if you had a rack of cell processor servers,
you could totally, yeah, I mean, Sony, let's do it.
- Yeah, right.
First they gotta work with IBM to start making that thing
again, 'cause you remember that was like a fork
of the PowerPC branch of processors.
It was a weird--
- I remember it ran Yellow Dog Linux.
I remember the Air Force was buying them,
left and right, yeah.
(laughing)
- Oh man, you know, it's funny, just a few days ago,
YouTube suggested to me a bunch of '80s and '90s commercials
and it's hard to really overstate,
'cause I don't think people realize it
if they weren't around back then,
but man, were they just such a quintessential part
of kid life and the way they sold stuff
and the way they integrated it with the cartoons
you were watching or the superheroes and all of that.
It started at the beginning of my lifetime,
the home consumer version in the early '80s
and by the late '80s and '90s,
they'd really just built a well-oiled machine.
It stumbled at first, but they eventually just built
this machine that made it just part of my lifestyle
and the discussion back then when I was a kid was,
well, will these people game when they're in their 30s
and 40s, 'cause nobody games in their 30s and 40s.
(laughs)
Well, they got us, they got us, it's great.
- Sure did.
- I think we should get a little nostalgic while we're here.
I'd love to know where you started with gaming.
- Yeah, so the first system of my own I had
was the Sega Genesis, the revised one that came out,
I think in 1993, and I played the hell out of Sonic 1.
I think I've bought that game on every single platform
it's available on.
- Yep, definitely has.
- It's definitely, yeah, definitely my favorite.
I had played Mario, NES, original Nintendo,
stuff like that before, but the first one of my own
was the Genesis, and yeah, I'm all about that Sega screen,
which I won't do because we'll blow out the levels
and the audio.
(laughs)
- We all know it.
It's integrated. - We all know it.
- At this point, it's in the DNA.
- Sega does, but it's not.
- I had such an interesting beginning with gaming consoles
because kids in the neighborhood had the Atari system.
My family, we didn't have any gaming systems,
but we had an Atari in the neighborhood
that I got to check out.
Then my dad, I lived with my mom at the time,
and then my dad ended up getting the Nintendo, the NES,
and I thought that was really neat,
and then some family members started getting the NES.
So when the Super Nintendo was announced,
I was like, "Oh, I'm gonna get the Nintendo."
So when the Super Nintendo was announced that year,
I went all in on the Ask for Christmas.
I did the big sell.
And I got it.
I got it.
And of course, my dad, at his house,
he picked up an SNES for himself and a Genesis.
So that was like, "Whoa, you have both?
"That's incredible."
But throughout all of this,
there always was a Mac or a PC around.
I got one of my very first games that I got really hooked on
was this game called Dark Castle.
It was this black and white platformer for the Mac.
(dramatic music)
It was just pretty low budge in terms of overall,
you know, you move through scenes statically.
- Dark Castle is a classic Macintosh game.
Many people also consider it to be
one of the worst games ever made,
thanks to a number of shoddy ports to other systems.
- And very hard game mechanics, like ridiculously hard.
You know, and you jump, you die,
you're going back to the beginning.
None of this do-over crap.
But that kind of stuff just drew me into the PC.
So very early on, I had a super strong attachment
to gaming on the computer,
but I loved the console stuff too.
So I've always kind of had my foot in both of those worlds.
Even today, what about you?
What's your system of choice today?
- Today, it's weirdly the Switch.
And maybe that's not that weird, right?
'Cause I play, in fact, I've just been playing
the Super Mario All-Stars Lost Levels,
which is for folks who maybe aren't this deep
into the nerdiness, is actually Japan's version
of Super Mario 2, which is basically Super Mario 1,
but really hard with just incredibly
aggressive level design.
I just beat that the other night.
And you know, the Switch is kind of a great balance for me,
having said that I have an Xbox S and a PS5
and God knows what else is lying around.
But I really, you know, I like some of the retro games.
It kind of is the ultimate nostalgia console,
and you just can't beat Nintendo's level design
if you like that classic platforming
or like Metroidvania style game.
Also the indie game scene on the Switch.
I spent a lot of time on indie games,
which is something I'm hoping, you know,
as we do this, we can feature.
Yeah, so currently the Switch.
Switch is killer.
Switch is probably the one I've,
the current console I spent the most time with.
So I guess I'd put my vote behind the Switch too.
Only this last six months kind of,
or three to four months kind of being edged out
by the Steam Deck, which I think is fantastic.
But the, I think, you know, if you could only buy one,
I think it'd probably be the Switch.
In part, I agree with you.
The other thing Nintendo not only does
with the level design that's just fantastic,
but they recognize that their characters
were like little mini celebrities really early on.
I think before a lot of video game makers did.
And they figured out how to,
I think it really clicked for them
when they did Super Mario Kart for the Super Nintendo.
And they realized, they originally was gonna be
a kart racing game of just generic characters.
But as they begun to work with the game and create it,
they realized they could put their characters in there
and give them the abilities their characters have.
And I think that's when it really clicked for Nintendo
that they've got something there that nobody else has.
And so that, and that was the 90s.
And they have just been iterating on that idea since then.
And I think the Switch is kind of
the premier version of that.
Plus the portability is great when you do
#tinyhomeliving like I do.
It's nice to not always be stuck to the TV
because sometimes, you know, that TV or that area is in use.
And so being portable is fantastic.
And then the other thing that's great is
my family's big on road trips.
So the kind of portability of the Switch
and the battery and all of that,
it just makes a great road trip device
that kids can play on while we're going down the road
for six hours.
So yeah, I like the Switch.
The deck I really love a lot.
I do kind of wish that the Switch had sort of
the graphics capabilities of the bigger consoles.
But when I want really nice graphics,
that's just when I switch to a PC.
That's when I play on a computer.
- Right, that's when I switch to like the PS5.
- Yeah, yeah.
Now the other area that's clearly been a big thing for me,
which wasn't early on, is the portability of it.
I did have like way back in the day,
I don't remember what Genesis called their portable device,
but I did have one--
- The Game Gear.
- Yeah, the Game Gear.
I had a Game Gear.
I didn't get a Game Boy.
- It ate batteries.
It ate batteries like me at a all-you-can-eat shrimp buffet.
- My dad had a Game Boy and I had a Game Gear, if I recall.
- And your dad made the better choice.
- Yeah, he did.
- I love my Sega, but they, that,
I did not have that thing 'cause it was one,
more expensive, and two, the battery.
I had the original Game Boy Slim
that was just black and white.
That was, and I had that thing for a long time.
- Yeah, the Game Gear was kind of known
to be a problem child too, because I had a,
when I was a kid, our house got broken into,
and the guy ransacked my room and my Game Gear was out
and he just didn't even bother taking it.
He just left it.
- I thought you were gonna say he saw the Game Gear
and left you a pack of batteries.
- Right.
He's like, "I don't have, I don't want that hassle."
Oh man, so yeah, and I did eventually, I think,
no, you know, I think I got my dad's Game Boy
after he was done with it.
I never got my own Game Boy.
I just like that the Switch lets me play
a lot of the classic games,
and they do a great job at that too.
- Well, Nintendo is always happy
to sell you stuff you've bought before.
- Absolutely.
So is the Star Trek franchise.
They both got me right where they want me.
Just buy the same thing over and over again.
But you, you also do Magic the Gathering type stuff
that I've never gotten into.
I don't know, my kids are huge into Pokemon too.
I've never gotten into that type of gameplay,
but I'm curious.
- I do it, I do it all, yeah.
I mean, back in the day, let's say the early aughts,
right, yeah, early aughts, I was very much
a DCI-ranked Magic the Gathering player,
back when they called it Type 2 instead of Standard.
But if you know anything about Magic, it's a long time ago.
- Is that like diabetes Type 2, or is that something else?
- It's the way they decide what cards are legal
in that specific tournament.
- Oh, okay.
- So they redid it while I was on hiatus, so to speak,
but it's basically you have, right now,
what they used to call Type 2 is called Standard,
and it's like the most recent sets.
It's their way of refreshing the card pool, right?
And there's, now they've added a bunch of new ones
like Pioneer and Commander.
- Okay.
- But yeah, it's, it's, Magic the Gathering is the thing
that once you start, it's like the dark side forever,
will it dominate your destiny?
- It sounds like it.
- I also play a crap ton of Pokemon TCG,
but that's mostly Kitchen Table with my six-year-old.
And I've been very much into flesh and blood recently.
In fact, I was at an Armory event last night,
which is flesh and blood's equivalent
of a Friday night Magic ranked event.
And I am proud to tell you, I went 0-4,
meaning I lost every single match.
- You're proud, you're proud of that, felt good, right?
- It's only my second one, I got crushed.
- Okay, okay.
(laughs)
The suffering's good, that's what you should tell yourself.
It's good to lose every now and then.
- You have to earn it, right?
- Yeah.
- Yeah, you have to earn it.
So, you know, definitely, like I love all kinds
of tabletop games, board games, I particularly have a yin
for card games, I've also noticed, and this is where
boring dad stuff comes out, my kid reacts differently
to having to solve a problem and say, for instance,
we play a lot of Ticket to Ride Junior, which is a game
where you're building train routes to get points.
Great game, the Junior one's really age appropriate
for that like, you know, five to seven age group.
And he just slows down a little bit and thinks more
in a step, almost algorithmic way, right?
Step by step way, rather than when we play
Super Smash Brothers, he just beats the crap out of me
'cause his reflexes are that much better than mine.
- Yeah, yeah, there's some games that create that kind
of way of thinking of problem solving or build
or order of execution, that that, I think,
is a good mental pathway to develop.
- Yeah, it's also a great bonding activity.
I mean, I know it can be a little tough playing
board games with little kids, right, 'cause you gotta watch,
they don't, you know, get a little creative,
and now you're missing pieces and you're mailing
the company, paying five bucks for like three little
plastic things, I'm not saying that this happened,
it definitely happened.
But once you get them in the habit, it's something
they can do with their friends.
For instance, Pokemon TCG came out when I was a kid,
and I think it's bigger than ever now.
- Yeah, isn't it remarkable?
- It's crazy, it's, I'm, and the game has actually managed
to add mechanics, but it's still not that complex.
It's, I mean, my six-year-old can pick it up,
we play it all the time, we play it almost probably
every day, like right after school, we take a break
without our, his favorite Cinderace deck,
and I have a metal deck, and it's, I gotta tell you,
it's incredible how they've kept to the spirit
of the original sets, right, and the flavor of the,
you know, I think, what was it, 1994, that Pokemon
Red and Blue came out in the States, it was in '95.
- That sounds about right, though.
- Yeah, but they've added all these new Pokemon
and new mechanics without making it like,
let's say, Yu-Gi-Oh! complicated, where if you ever
watch people playing Yu-Gi-Oh! on YouTube now,
it's one guy's turn takes 20 minutes, so there's that.
But how about you, so no cards, no tabletop?
- No, let's see, I was trying to think, did I ever dabble?
Not really, although I do feel like I deeply respect
what, how that Pokemon brand has continued.
There's gotta be a YouTube documentary out there,
if anybody knows, send it our way.
So I'm able to watch them from afar and be like,
yeah, that does look like a lot of fun.
Like, I've watched my oldest really develop
the passion for the trading aspect, and now he's picked up
other games, for better or for worse, that involve trading
like on the iPad using Scam Simulator X, and that kind
of stuff, he loves that stuff now.
- Scam Simulator?
- Yeah, that's what we call it, 'cause it's full of scams.
Yeah, it's Pet Simulator is what they call it, and you go
in there and it's kind of like a Pokemon ripoff in Roblox.
And it's got hundreds, like this Saturday, this last Saturday
they had like 600,000 kids on there at the same time.
- Oh, what?
- Yeah, yeah.
- That's just a server infrastructure story right there.
- No kidding, no kidding.
- It's funny you mention Roblox, I don't remember
how old kids are exactly, but my son has been lobbying me
for Roblox and I've been pretty resistant.
- It's a pit, man, because it's a game with a bunch
of other games inside of it, and so they can just keep
kind of doom-swiping through games, and they're all fueled
by Roblox, or Robux, the currency, and then a lot
of these games have their own sub-currencies, multiple.
And it's a hot mess, and so you inevitably as a parent
get pressured into this subscription paradigm they have,
so that way your kid can get issued Robux on a regular
basis, if you can avoid it I would.
- See, this is why I don't like the iPad games at all,
because what I like to do is throughout the year
when Nintendo, because he has a Switch as well,
does their sales, Amazon will cut, because I like to buy
the physical cartridges, Amazon will do a lightning sale,
whatever, right?
- Yeah, I have a couple of them on Camel, Camel, Camel
just in case the price goes down and I'll pick it up.
- Yeah, well that's what I do, when they go down
I just jump on it and buy it.
And for let's say 30 bucks, I mean a good Nintendo game
is at least 30, 40 hours.
And especially for a kid who, at least mine,
is something of a completionist, so he'll explore ever,
like he's gotta get all the stars in Mario, right?
He's gotta, oh I beat it with Mario, well now I gotta
do the Luigi version, right?
I can't tell you how much of Luigi's Mansion I've seen.
Truly horrific.
But yeah, I feel like those iPad games are,
they're not all bad and I know good people on this call
who are developing one right now.
But the incentives seem super icky for the developers.
- Yeah, and since everything's kind of going to a
subscription model, because that's the only sustainable
development revenue they can seem to make, it feels like
they have to get spicier and spicier in how they get you
to subscribe and get that coin, it's so frustrating.
And you're right, the problem is the kids love it
as a device for that kind of stuff.
But you're right, I think as a parent, it's better to have
them on a completely separate device for gaming if possible
because so many of those iPad games inevitably,
and you know, by the way, by the way, you know how I was
mentioning we were checking out some of their really
super old original games that they felt really nostalgic
about, well guess what isn't loaded up with like
subscription options and in-app currencies?
- These older games. - Old iPad games.
- Yeah. - You bought them for five
or 10 bucks. - Right.
- I mean, we talk about this a lot on Coda, right?
The monetization model for iOS development used to be
very honestly, I think a lot more bare, right?
More honest. - Yeah.
So that's an interesting insight.
It's something I'm gonna think more about.
I mean, the Switch and the games are a lot of money,
but it might ultimately, when you consider they ask
for robux all the time or the subscription prices,
it might actually be cheaper.
- I hate to say it, God.
- Well, and they're more full-featured experiences, right?
Like if you think about the design, and this is something
that really struck me as I was playing Lost Levels,
Mario Lost Levels, someone sat there with graph paper
and like designed this level out and really did a great job
where, and there are good mobile games, don't get me wrong,
but a lot of them are kind of a, basically a loop of,
you know, buy resources, exhaust resources in that purchase,
buy resources, right?
- There are a few standouts, and maybe this will set you up
for what you're playing this week, because I've had a busy
couple of weeks doing doubles for the holidays and whatnot.
As you know, we did one for Coder, and I find the Altos
Odyssey type game just that, and they have a zen mode,
which I think is fantastic, so you can just keep playing
even after you crash, and so there's a type of mobile game
for me that when they're not too grabby, ascii,
and they build a really nice game that's just super smooth
and chill to play, that's worth it, you know, and that,
to me, I'll pay for that, that's great, and so one of the
nice things is I've picked that up, and I'll bust it out
just in the evening, just as a little like chill down,
kind of just wind down kind of game, and if you haven't
played it, it's fantastic, and there's no subscription,
there's no currency that you have to buy to be able
to unlock stuff, there's a game mode where you unlock levels
through a traditional just by playing and proceeding
through the game, and then there's just the zen mode
where it's a constant play mode, and you just keep on
playing right through, and if you crash, you just get up
and keep going, and it's one of those surfing games.
I really like it, it's Altos, it's been around for a while,
there's a couple of them.
What about you, what are you enjoying this week?
- Well, this week, I definitely binged on the Super Mario
Lost levels, went from zero to beating it, that was kind of
my wind down evening game, I've also picked up a Marvel
Midnight Sun, which is a, have you seen this, it's a
tactical strategy game built by the folks who built X-Com.
- Oh. - But using Marvel characters,
yeah. - Okay, okay, and how is it?
You liking it? - It is very good,
but it is definitely like baby X-Com.
It has this card mechanic, which ironically, for someone
who loves playing card games, I kind of find annoying.
- Yes, I sometimes do in these type of games, it seems
like it just slows everything down.
- Yeah, it's, I can see where they were going with it.
There was an old Kingdom Hearts game, I think for the DS,
I want to say, although those games are hard because they
ported them everywhere over the years.
That had a similar mechanic where you had to like have
your deck for each character, and it's definitely, I feel
like Aspire, who I believe is a developer on this,
executed it better than the Kingdom Hearts folks did.
But it is totally, it's one of those things where I'm like,
if this wasn't Marvel, would I have bought it?
Right, like if I couldn't have Doctor Strange make his
weird witty comments as he does a magical axe
in someone's face.
- Does it feel well integrated, does it feel true
to the Marvel characters in universe, or does it feel like
it's a game engine that has these skins and sounds
layered on top of it?
- No, the character personality is the story.
I mean, they definitely did their work on the Marvel side.
It's, yeah, like Tony Stark feels exactly like, you know,
Robert Downey Jr.'s Tony Stark, right?
Spider-Man, it's Peter Parker, feels like.
- Yeah, right.
- The strangeness comes in where, and one of the problems
is one of my favorite PC games is X-Com, and I'm just about
to start X-Com 2 at some point, even though I bought it
three years ago at full price for no reason.
(laughing)
I could have picked it up for eight bucks over the
winter sale.
- Yeah, it's my move, I know that move.
- I just waited.
And I'm used to, like in X-Com, right, you've probably
played it.
- Yeah, yeah, yeah.
- Yeah, permadeath, right, you have like all, like your
decisions count a lot more.
And the character progression I think is a little richer,
and I'm just talking X-Com 1 here, so I don't, you know,
enemy unknown.
I have no idea about X-Com 2, which I have to try out.
So also, by the way, X-Com 1, very good on the iPad.
- Ah, interesting, I wouldn't have thought of it, but of
course it makes sense.
That does actually seem, so they had to port it clearly,
so they did an okay job then.
- Yeah, I mean, it doesn't look as great as it does on,
say, a high-end PC, but it looks fine.
I mean, it looks, I would say, bad as good as the old Mac
version, but you can't play anymore on modern Mac OS,
'cause it's 32-bit.
The grid and the touch controls make a ton of sense, right?
You tap your soldier, you tap where you want him to go.
Pretty, pretty intuitive.
Yeah, I mean, Midnight Suns is good.
I would recommend it if you're a Marvel fan, but if you're
like a hardcore tactical strategy fan, it's probably gonna
feel a little too, like, pedestrian to you.
- I just started playing Metroid Dread, because they updated
it with a rookie mode to make it slightly easier, because
they just don't have the time to really get super good at it.
Have you played Dread?
- I have purchased it.
- Okay, yeah, I purchased it, I sat on it for a while, and
they just did an update to make it slightly easier, but it
is, so it's a classic side-scroller, like, I think I prefer
Metroid, the 3D games were fun, but I think I prefer Metroid
as a 2D side-scroller, it's one of my all-time favorites,
and this one is, you really move fast.
There's this mechanic where you can deflect, you can kind of
do this deflection move, and if you nail the timing just
perfect, in some circumstances, you have a chance to
survive, and if you fail, you die.
It's just like you're immediately dead, because there's some
monsters in here that are very, very powerful, and so it's
one part, move as quick as possible, two parts, deflect
just at the right time, and then three parts, figure out
the combos for your fingers to activate the weapons, but it
all feels like it makes sense, all the controls feel like,
once I've learned which ones I have to hold down, like,
oh yeah, okay, that feels kind of intuitive, I think they'll
stick between gameplay sessions, and the graphics are
beautiful, it's a great example of a beautiful game on the
Switch, I don't think it's particularly demanding in terms
of 3D rendering, but there are some 3D scenes, and the space
is obviously a 3D space that they have the cameras pinned,
but yeah, I like it a lot so far, I've played the first
couple levels, I found it really hard, I had to message a
buddy, I'm like, what do you do to get away from the dog?
You move fast, that's what you do, but I like it a lot so
far, I think it's a classic Metroid game, it's just one of
the harder, intense ones.
- Yeah, I've always, it's funny, I love the rogues' legacy,
like the descendants of Metroid and Castlevania, and I've
only ever played two Castlevanias and zero Metroids.
- Really, oh, Metroid's such a great game.
- Yeah, it's on my list to go back for a little retro section.
- Yeah, it's great on the Super Nintendo version, I think
is peak video game, period, like just the layers to it,
and the way you progress, and then the secrets you unlock,
and the aha moments you get, it's all really great, I mean,
I think it holds up as one of the greats.
- Yeah, yeah, it's worth that Super Nintendo, and you've got
it on the Switch there, if you've got the network stuff.
- I have all three of them, of course.
- Mwah, mwah, of course.
- Although the N64 one's a bit busted, but yeah.
- So I assume you'll be doing more magic over the holidays
and whatnot.
- Yes, depending on the results of the Discord poll that my
local game store put up, if people wanna play it tomorrow,
I will be playing, not Commander, I'm sorry, Pioneer.
- You are so deep, oh my goodness.
- I am so deep, yeah, which is a one-on-one
competitive format.
You can look at my Moxfield link from my deck list.
It's a red, green, gruel mid-range deck, which basically
it's a aggressive deck that wants to hit you in the face
with creatures, and when, you know, like turn seven or eight,
right, so it's not, aggro would be like turn two,
like three or four.
So this is a little slower.
Yeah, it's performed pretty well.
One of the nice things about being a little bit of an old
hand at MTGs, I built my deck and Pioneer's a long-lasting
format, unlike Standard, so I can keep this deck for a long
time and avoid spending too much money on it.
That's what flesh and blood is for.
Yeah, it's a little weird with this being Christmas week,
right, 'cause like last night there wasn't that many folks
at the flesh and blood event.
I would highly recommend, by the way, if you're,
do I also play Arena, Magic Arena, which is digital magic
on iPad, if you're just playing Arena, it's great.
Don't get me wrong, I play it all the time.
In fact, I'll put my Arena username,
it's on Twitter somewhere, and hit me up,
but if you have a local game store, try going to either
a casual commander event, which is a four-player format,
or really any, like a draft is easy 'cause you just need
three booster packs, the experience of playing in person,
I think, and I understand it's super tough to meet new
people and you might be shy, I can be too, but it's such
a better experience when you start playing with a regular
group, and 'cause the iPad game is really very grindy,
right, it's very mechanical.
Yeah, so it's all about community, right, Linux people?
You know what, it's cheesy and cliche, but it is so true,
it does make it more fun, I have so much more fun playing
with family members and friends than I do just off on my own
unless it's a chill-out game, then I can do that on my own.
But yeah.
Yeah, or it's a Jet Set Radio future, but we'll talk about
the Dreamcast maybe another day.
Oh, we totally should.
Yeah, the most technologically advanced console for its
time that probably they should have put less effort into.
I also could have, if we wanna do another nostalgic chat
sometime, I spent quite a bit of time with the Saturn CD,
the Sega CD, I mean, I don't know if you ever played any
of the Sega CD games, but.
I did for the three weeks it was out, yeah.
Oh, slow CD rocks.
I had the 32X add-on for the Genesis.
Nice.
Not really, it immediately failed.
Yeah, it was good, it was cool, they reproduced the X-Wing,
remember the old X-Wing arcade game that you'd sit there
and they had the booth-style arcade cabinet.
Yeah.
They did a really nice reproduction of that.
They only sold like five of them, but Sega.
You know, I think, assuming we get good feedback
from you guys, so make sure you @Mrs. Chris.
Yeah, let us know, I think some of the best ways
to let us know what you think is probably
the Matrix chat room, you can grab us in there.
Just the Coda Radio General for now as we're farting
around here getting this thing going, but your feedback
helps it turn into a real boy, and we love that.
Yeah, also you can use the Coda.show/contact page
and you can send your feedback for gamer radio there
'cause we can parse, you know what, we can figure that out.
We can parse, we can figure that out.
And let us know if you want the Sega Memorial episode.
(laughing)
Yeah, oh jeez, all right, well in the meantime,
where's a way they could let you know directly
what they thought, Ms. Twitter besides Matrix,
is Twitter good, you still over there?
Yep, I'm @jimunoko on Twitter and @jimunoko on Mastodon.
Very good, you can find me over there too,
I'm @chrislias, I am on the Mastos, turns out.
Turns out I've been on there since 2017, who knew?
You can find me over there as well.
But I think the Matrix is probably the best,
jupiterbroadcasting.com/matrix.
Dig around in there and you'll find me.
Thanks for joining us, hope to see you soon.
(upbeat music)
(upbeat music)
(upbeat music)
(upbeat music)
(upbeat music)
(upbeat music)
(upbeat music)
(upbeat music)
(upbeat music)
(upbeat music)
(gentle music)
(gentle music)
(gentle music)

metadata.title: Coder Radio gamer: Gaming with Perspective

episode.title: Gamer Radio Gaming with Perspective - Test Show | Coder Radio
episode.description: Mike and Chris spend a little time chatting about one of their loves in life, great games. It's a test pilot episode for a possible new show, and we'd like your feedback. Consider it a holiday treat for the Coder fans out there.
episode.content:
Mike and Chris spend a little time chatting about one of their loves in life, great games. It's a test pilot episode for a possible new show, and we'd like your feedback. Consider it a holiday treat for the Coder fans out there.
